title: Can you get away with not paying a speeding ticket? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the U.S., I suppose you could, providing You never drove a car again in the U.S.You never again had contact with a law enforcement officer in that state.You didn’t need to pass a background investigation in the U.S.You didn’t need to have a valid drivers license.If you get a ticket and ignore it, the court that receives the ticket from the law enforcement agency that issues it will likely issue an arrest warrant for your failure to appear. The amount of the bail on the arrest warrant will be some multiple of the original fine amount. In most cases, the court will send a letter to your most recently known address and advise you of the warrant. Whether this notice reaches you, or even that they notice you at all, has nothing to do with the validity of the warrant. I point this out because some people think the defense of “I never knew I had a warrant” absolves them of responsibility for it. Not so. Also, in most cases, no one will go to any trouble at all to find you to answer to the warrant. It will go into a file, and be recorded on the regional criminal justice network that area agencies use. Should you have no further contact with law enforcement, that’s probably where it will remain. In most states, the court will notify the drivers license bureau, which will suspend your license. If you get pulled over, you’ll be driving while suspended. In some places, that means a mandatory arrest and/or mandatory impoundment of your car. Should you have a police contact and the officer runs your name (which is a very common practice, even if you are a complainant or witness), the warrant will pop up, and the cop will arrest you. If you don’t happen to have the bail on you, and either can’t contact a bondsman or they’re not available where you live, you will sit in jail until you go before a judge. There, the judge will decide whether to hold you, or release you pending trial on the original charge. You could also plead guilty to all of it on the spot, and be sentenced immediately. In any event, it will be an unpleasant experience. My recommendation: if you truly believe you’re not guilty of whatever you were cited for, ask for a trial date and contest the ticket. If you did the crime, then pay the fine and move on.

Answering if you are in the States. Nope. It’s attached to your license. If you don’t pay it, your license will be flagged. Next time it is run by an officer, you will most likely be arrested. Even if the system doesn’t send you anything, you still should plan to show up at the listed court on the day and time of the ticket. Make sure you get any changes in writing. I had an incident where I never got a notice and lost the original ticket. I got a summons saying I had to show up or a warrant would be issued. I showed up and explained to the judge who was extremely fair about the whole thing. Wiped the warrant and the extra fees. Gave me 60 days to pay the fine. I had called the court and issuing agency after a couple weeks of getting the ticket, but no letter. They couldn’t find the ticket in the system and told me to not worry about it. That they would send me something when the ticket hit the system. Another story, make sure to NEVER throw out anything. I had a girlfriend who had gotten a ticket, done traffic school and paid the fines. During a changeover from analogue records to digital, her completion of the process had been omitted. She got arrested and they were going to impound her car, but a friend parked it for her. She was able to take care of everything, but the cops were total assholes to her the whole time. (so, basically, cops) Pay your ticket, fight it if you want, but if they offer traffic school, just take it. The American “infraction” traffic system is all about making money and everybody with a badge or a robe is in on it.

Tough piece of advice to give. If you’re handed a criminal citation you should take care of it. If you get it in the mail that is not proper service of summons and you can throw it in the trash and deny you ever got it. But MOST people pay the ticket, whether or not it was delivered via the accepted rules of jurisprudence. If you’re stopped by the police and cited for exceeding the speed limit why not either pay the ticket or demand to be taken before a magistrate. If you do so the officer is required to arrest you and take you immediately to court. (Note: Night magistrates will be thoroughly pissed off if you show up at 11:00 pm to deal with a speeding ticket unless you are absolutely certain the officer was incorrect in his / her determination of your speed.)

No. You are required to appear or otherwise properly take care of the citation by a certain date. If you do nothing there will be a bench warrant for your arrest. Depending on the jurisdiction, they may also freeze or suspend your registration, suspend your driver license and/or put you in collections.
In New York state, as long as you never drive again, you can get away with not paying the ticket. If you drive again, you can be arrested for the crime of aggravated unlicensed operation.
You can fight it in court, but you are at great peril if you attempt to ignore it.
In many states they will suspend your drivers license til you pay the fines. If you drive without a license and they catch you then you will have more fines.
